results.title: Intravenous anaesthesia. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Realist Films, ICI (GB) and Yvonne Fletcher
results.brief_description: Deals with the general principles of administering intravenous anaesthetic, including demonstrations of essential apparatus, technique of venepuncture, course of anaesthesia with sodium pentothal, and the dangers against which to guard.

results.title: Intolerance [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Wark Producing Corporation, Majestic Motion Pictures and D.W. Griffith
results.brief_description: Stung by criticism of racism after “The Birth of a nation”, director D.W. Griffith made amends with his next feature “Intolerance”. Set over the ages, this is an epic silent film, a tale of misguided human nature expressed through the themes of intolerance, hypocrisy and treachery. The film consists of four tales: A modern story (a poor but loving family are persecuted by a group of judgemental women who seek to take the couple’s small child, fearing its neglect); A Judean story (relates the last days of Jesus Christ); A French story (set in 15th century, detailing the persecution of the Huguenots by Catherine de Medici); A Babylonian story (traces the defeat of King Belshazzar by the hordes of Cyrus the Persian). The four stories are interwoven, which makes for challenging viewing, and on this DVD, the option exists to watch the four narratives separately. Griffith used a variety of tinted film stock for dramatic effect on a scale seldom equalled in silent cinema. One of the most influential films in the history of cinema, the four stories culminate in a climax of cross cutting. Each drama illustrates the operation and catastrophic consequences of intolerance.

results.title: Intolerance
results.brief_description:
Griffith used a variety of tinted film stock for dramatic effect on a scale seldom equalled in silent cinema. One of the most influential films in the history of cinema, on the theme of man’s intolerance throughout the ages, told in four separate but interwoven stories—’Fall of Babylon’, ‘Passion of Christ’, ‘Massacre of St. Bartholomew’ and ‘The mother and the law’—which culminate in a climax of cross cutting. Alternate versions also available on 16mm and VHS.
Credits: Director, writer, D. W. Griffith ; photography, G. W. Bitzer ; production designer, Frank “Huck” Wortman ; music, Joseph Carl Breil, D.W. Griffith ; editor, James Smith, Rose Smith.
Cast: Lillian Gish, Mae Marsh, Robert Harron, Miriam Cooper, Walter Long, Tully Marshall.

results.title: Into your hand
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Denys Brown, Stanley Hawes and Rhonda Small
results.brief_description: A plea to preserve Australia’s native animals. Describes the native fauna and how white settlement, expansion, and clearing land has effected them. Shows how animals such as the red kangaroo, possums, lizards, and ablbatross are caught and banded to enable scientists to study closely their living habits. Professor A.J. marshall questions random methods of pest killing.

results.title: Into the west
results.brief_description: Gabriel Burn stars as a widower and former gypsy king who has rejected his nomadic ancestry to settle with his two boys amid the grim tower blocks of Dublin. He is far from the perfect father, spending most of the time in the pub while his children tend to themselves. Their life is magically altered by the arrival of their grandfather with a magnificent white stallion called Tir na nOg, a figure out of Irish legend. The children, Ossie and Tito, take an instant shine to the horse, but events beyond their control occur when the horse is impounded by corrupt police officials. Ossie and Tito begin a desperate mission to regain the stallion that has brought happiness to their lives. This fantasy come Western is set against the magnificent Irish backdrop, and is as much a story about a father’s redemption as it is about searching for happiness and adventure. Cast includes Ellen Barkin, Ruaidhri Conroy and Ciaran Fitzgerald. Written by Jim Sheridan.

results.title: Into the straight
results.creator_credit: Embassy Pictures Corporation (US), McCreadie Bros and T.O. McCreadie
results.brief_description: A melodrama, partly shot on location at Scone, N.S.W., involving romance and intrigue against a background of the world of horse racing and culminating in the Melbourne Cup. The film follows the fortunes of a racehorse breeding family, the Curzons, who need to strengthen their blood stock to re establish a fading reputation. This results in the purchase of a champion English horse, along with a father and son training team. Rivalry develops between the men for the love of the Curzon daughter, and for the attentions of a femme fatale nightclub singer, Zara Marlowe. A mock race was staged at Flemington and Randwick for the film and famous jockeys of the time, Jack Purcell and George Moore make brief personal appearances. Cast includes Charles Tingwell, Muriel Steinbeck and Nonnie Peifer.
